Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of volatile organic compounds in antagonistic selection in the moss Ceratodon purpureus
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate how differences in natural selection on males and females effects the genetic basis of scent differences in the moss, Ceratodon purpureus. In many plants and animals, males and females exhibit many differences in form and physiology. These differences are thought to arise because qualities that are beneficial in one sex may be deleterious in the opposite sex. Although physical differences between males and females are very conspicuous, we have a poor understanding of the genetic mechanisms that generate these differences, and many of their benefits. In Ceratodon, female mosses produce scents to attract small insects that carry sperm from male plants, promoting reproduction, while male plants make few such scents. This research will test the idea that the production of these scents is costly in males, and that the genes for scent production are present but turned off in males. In addition, the project will involve mentoring both undergraduate and high school students, including individuals from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences.

The project will use quantitative genetics and transcriptomic experiments to understand the evolutionary forces shaping sexually dimorphic scent profiles. Scents are comprised of a cocktail of volatile organic compunds (VOC). Measures of VOC production in a pedigreed population is providing an estimate of the additive genetic variance and covariance for VOC production in males and females. Competitive mating trials will be used to evaluate the fitness consequences of variation in VOC production in males and females, both in the presence and absence of sperm-dispersing arthropods. RNAseq analyses in high and low VOC producing males and females will be used in conjunction with existing biochemical pathway databases to identify transcripts linked to VOC production. The transcriptomic work will lay the foundation for studying the resolution of genome-wide genetic conflict.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Leslie Kollar has completed her dissertation “The Genetic Basis of Volatile Production in the moss Ceratodon purpureus” with the support of the National Science Foundation’s Dissertation Improvement Grant (DDIG). During her dissertation work, the DDIG afforded her the opportunity to travel to Portland State University where she learned methods in mass spectrometry (GC-TOF-MS and PTR-TOF-MS) to compliment her quantitative genetics focused research goals. The research Kollar completed during her dissertation focused on uncovering the underlying genetic architecture for scent production and other life history traits using a diverse dataset including phenotypic data, multiple types of mass spectrometry data, ddrRADseq, and RNAseq data.

 

The moss C purpureus, is sexually dimorphic throughout its life cycle but most notably for its scent production where the females produce a greater variety and quantity of scents. These scents attract sperm dispersing microarthropods thereby increase the number of fertilization events much like plant and insect interactions in flowering plants. The fact that C. purpureus is sexually dimorphic at all stages of the life cycle suggests that many traits could be under sexual conflict. In natural populations, sexual conflict can prevent the sexes from reaching their respective trait optima and thus produce low fitness individuals. Natural selection would inevitably purge low fitness individuals from the population however, research has observed low fitness individuals to persist. The broad goal of this dissertation was to understand the mechanisms allowing for a variety of traits to exist in a population despite potentially negative effects on fitness. This research addressed 3 fundamental questions in evolutionary biology 1.) to what extent can sexual dimorphism in this moss still evolve, 2.) what is the genetic architecture of scent production, and 3.) what is the role of the U and V sex chromosomes in sexual dimorphism.  

 

Kollar found many scents and leaf traits to be sexually dimorphic with females generally having larger leaves and higher emissions of scents. Single traits analyses on development and total number of scents produced suggest that if selection were to select for faster development or a larger variety of scents to be produced in females, their brothers would also be selected for in the same manor despite potential fitness consequences. However, since some traits may be correlated with other traits within a single sex, when selection acts on one trait other traits are indirectly affected regardless of fitness consequences. Thus, to understand potential constraint on the evolution of sexual dimorphism, Kollar investigated how suites of traits could become more dimorphic between the sexes. She determined that sexual dimorphism in suits of traits is constrained due to both sex- specific selective pressures and similar selective pressures.  Thus, although many traits are already sexually dimorphic there is a large potential for further evolution of sexual dimorphism.  Additionally, Kollar was able to identify genes associated with scent production some of which showed great potential for further experimentation to confirm the genes role in scent production. Remarkably some of these genes lie within a large chromosomal inversion and on the U and V sex chromosomes. This finding suggests that the underlying genetic architecture of scent production and other growth and developmental traits may be even more complex then once thought.

 

Aside from various research findings, this research has established 352 lines of C. purpureus that could be used for further experimentation to investigate fitness consequences and a more in-depth study of the genetic architecture. These lines include data ranging from phenotypic data throughout the plant’s life cycle to multiple forms of sequence data (RNA and ddradSeq). All data and code has been made freely available on public repositories such as GitHub and Dryad.

 

Lastly, this research has trained 12 undergraduate researchers at the University of Florida and 4 undergraduate researchers at Portland State University. Many of the students mentored during the duration of this project were neurodiverse or non- traditional students (<22 years old), historically underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Undergraduate researchers were supported and encouraged to present research findings on campus and at national conferences. Several students made important contributions and were included in the publication process.
